Description: A double-sided flask with similar Janiform heads of Harpokrates (or perhaps of a childlike Bes): he has vertical locks over his forehead and falling on each side of his face. His tongue is slightly extended, and he wears a diadem in the centre of which is a wedjat eye flanked on each side by a transverse bar and a boss. The narrow neck of the vessel, broken at the mouth, has a handle on each side, voluted at the lower spring. Harpokrates' neck is cut off by a flat base. Two-piece mould. Micaceous dark brown to grey Nile silt, with a black slip (Memphis Black Ware).
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Ptolemaic: second or first century BC.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3080)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
